Chapter 1: Distinguishing Differences, Part 1 of 2. Having listed the faculties in this way, one should now contemplate further:
Why did the World-Honored One separately speak of the name of faculties?
The entire internal realms and one part of the dharma realms are separately spoken of as faculties based on the meaning of predominance, because they attain predominance in each matter.
This meaning of predominance clarifies the meaning of realms.
Realm means Ä«Å›vara or ká¹£etra, the meaning of Ä«Å›vara is supreme and sovereign, the meaning of ká¹£etra is illuminating and clear.
Only this flourishing and manifest is called a faculty. This meaning generally indicates the twenty-two faculties, whose function is predominant in various aggregates.

Because each of the dharmas has a superior function with regard to the others, all should be called roots. However, only the most superior are given the name. This is like the lion king, the head of a village, or a universal monarch, who are the most superior among animals, villages, and the four continents, respectively.
With regard to what are these superior functions?
The verse states:
It is said that the five are superior to the four, and the four roots are superior to the two kinds.
The five and the eight are superior in the defiled and pure realms, respectively.
The treatise states:
Not all faculties are the most superior with regard to a single thing.
The five faculties such as the eye each have a superior function with regard to four things: 1) adorning the body, 2) nourishing the body, 3) producing consciousness, etc., and 4) unique functions.
As for adorning the body, it means that if any one of the five faculties is missing, the body is ugly.
As for nourishing the body, it means that based on seeing and hearing, one avoids danger and difficulty, and is able to enjoy material food.
The three of smell, taste, and touch are all categorized as food by mouthfuls. As a verse says:
Just as a person with clear eyes can avoid present dangers,
In the world, there are those who are wise and can avoid future suffering and evil.
The learned can understand the Dharma, the learned can avoid wrongdoing,
The learned abandon what is meaningless, the learned attain nirvana.
The body depends on food for existence, life depends on food for preservation, after eating, it causes the mind to
be comfortable and at ease.

As for producing consciousness, etc., it refers to producing the five consciousnesses and their associated dharmas, because the clarity or obscurity of the consciousnesses depends on the faculties that support them.
The unique function refers to apprehending its own object, because it sees, hears, smells, tastes, and cognizes its own object.
Some say:
The eye and ear have a dominant influence in protecting the body born of the elements and the Dharma body, respectively, in that order. The first two verses are evidence for this.
Some say:

The eyes and ears each have a dominant influence on two things: the eye and ear each have a dominant influence on the preservation of the two bodies, the physical body and the Dharma body, because they enable one to approach good people and listen to the true Dharma.
The female, male, life, and mind faculties each have a dominant influence on two things.
As for the two dominant influences of the female and male faculties, the first is the difference in sentient beings, and the second is the difference in discrimination.

As for the difference in sentient beings, in the beginning of the eon, the forms and types of sentient beings were all the same. After the two faculties appeared, there were distinctions in the forms and types of females and males.
As for the difference in discrimination, there are distinctions in the postures, speech, breasts, hair buns, etc. of females and males.
Some say:

Because there are differences in courage and fear, it is called the difference in sentient beings. Because there are differences in clothing and adornments, it is called the difference in discrimination.
Some say:

This has a dominant influence on both defiled and pure categories, therefore it is said that it has a dominant influence on the reception of unwholesome disciplines and the performance of uninterrupted evil deeds, and the severing of wholesome roots, which is called having a dominant influence on the defiled category;
Because it can receive precepts, enter the path, attain the fruit, and be free from desire, it is said to have superior power in the pure category.
The bodies of eunuchs and so forth do not have such things.

As for the life faculty having superior power in two ways, it is said that because of this, the various faculties and distinctions among faculties are established. Because when this exists, they exist; when this does not exist, they do not exist.
Or, in the formless realm, there must be the life faculty in order for the place of rebirth to be determined.
Because it gives rise to wholesome or defiled minds of its own realm, or gives rise to other minds, but not because of death.
As for the mental faculty having superior power in two ways, it is said that it can continue subsequent existence and can freely follow.
As for being able to continue subsequent existence, it is as the World-Honored One told Ä€nanda:
If consciousness does not enter the mother's womb, can semen and blood form the kalala?
No, World-Honored One!
And so on, speaking in detail.
As for freely following, as a sutra says:
The mind can guide the world, the mind can universally accept,
Thus, this one dharma of the mind, all freely follow it.
Some say:
The mental faculty has the power of predominance in both the defiled and pure categories, therefore it is said to be in both. As a scripture says:
Because the mind is defiled, sentient beings are defiled; because the mind is purified, sentient beings are purified.

The five faculties such as pleasure have the power of predominance in both defilement and purity. The five such as pleasure have the power of predominance in defilement, because they are the basis for the latent tendencies of craving, etc.
Some say:
These have the power of predominance in both the defiled and pure categories, because they are said to be the basis for indulgence and for renunciation.
Because scriptures say, Because of pleasure, the mind is concentrated, and Suffering is the basis for faith, etc.
The eight faculties such as faith have the power of predominance in purity, as a scripture says:
Our holy disciples are endowed with the ramparts of faith, the power of diligence, the defense of mindfulness, the sword of wisdom in the liberation of mental concentration, and so on at length.
Herein, the latter three faculties are included.
Therefore, they definitely have predominance in the pure category.
The initial transmission says:
It is said that pleasure is manifested later.
That is to say, some say:

The function of consciousness, not that of the eye, etc., is predominant in guiding and nourishing the body, because one is able to avoid danger and accept material food only by means of the consciousnesses that perceive favorable and unfavorable objects.

They also say that the unique function of seeing form, etc., is not different from consciousness, so the unique function cannot be established as a separate predominant activity for the faculties such as the eye. Therefore, the eye, etc., do not become faculties by means of this.
If that is so, then what?
The verse says:
The six faculties are generally established based on the predominance of perceiving their own objects.
Two faculties are established based on the body: the female and male faculties have predominance in gender.
Because of the predominance in the defilement and purity of the mixed states.
It should be known that the life faculty and the five feelings, faith and so forth, are established as faculties,
The faculties of one who is to know the unknown, one who knows, and one who has completed knowledge are also like this,
Because of the predominance in attaining the subsequent paths, nirvana, and so forth.
The treatise says:

As for understanding one's own objects, it refers to the six groups of consciousness. The five faculties such as the eye have a predominant function in the consciousness that distinguishes each specific object, while the sixth mental faculty has a predominant function in the consciousness that distinguishes all objects. Therefore, the eye and the other six are each established as a faculty.

However, there is no error in establishing as a faculty even that which does not have an object, because the eye and other faculties are the common cause for the consciousness that distinguishes all objects, and because the consciousness only has clarity or obscurity according to the faculties.
This explanation is unreasonable, because the homogeneous faculties should not be faculties.
Don't you also have this error?
We do not have this error, because we say that they have a predominant function in adorning the body.
Also, the eye is not the common cause of all consciousnesses that perceive form, because the eye is momentary and the consciousnesses that perceive form are not simultaneous.
If you say that the eye is not differentiated, then form also should not be differentiated, because the class of form is not differentiated.
If you say that blue and yellow are differentiated, then the eye also should be differentiated, because the eye is differentiated as being retribution or being nourished.

This is not a reason, because the substance of consciousness must be born before it can be clear or unclear according to the organ. If it is not born, it is not born, even if it is assisted by the dominant force of the organ.
Or, consciousness is clear or unclear according to the organ.

The function of guiding and nourishing the body should be attributed to the organ, because when the function of the eye is strong, it produces a strong consciousness that can avoid danger and guide and nourish the body.

When the function of the eye is weak, it produces a weak consciousness that does not understand danger and causes the body to fall into it. Therefore, guiding and nourishing the body is a function of the organ, not of consciousness.
What little difference is there between this and the previous explanation?

The previous explanation has already shown that the eyes and other faculties generate the eye consciousness and other consciousnesses and their associated dharmas. Now this explanation briefly mentions a part of that, but it is not what we see. What is there to rejoice in?
Since there is no separate meaning, it should not be explained again.
Also, your statement that the function of seeing form, etc., is not different from consciousness is also not so, because consciousness can see, etc., as has been previously refuted.
That is to say, the eye consciousness is not the substance that can see, because it is no different from the ear consciousness, etc.
Difficulties such as these are explained in detail above.
Also, those who establish the two faculties of male and female based on the body do so because of their predominance in the natures of male and female.
That is to say, in the female nature, the female faculty is predominant, and in the male nature, the male faculty is predominant.
The natures of male and female refer to the different bodily forms, voices, activities, and inclinations of the two sexes, male and female.
The substance of the male and female faculties is not separate from the body faculty, because it is given this name on the basis of a part of the body.

This place is slightly different from other places in terms of the body faculty. It is said that in the desire realm, a part of the body faculty can only serve as the support for giving rise to the unwholesome body consciousness that arises together with craving. Therefore, two faculties are established separately from the body faculty.

Even though there is the body faculty in the period at the beginning of the eon, etc., there is no difference in physical form, etc., between male and female. Therefore, two faculties should be established separately from that.

This also does not go beyond the meaning within the previous section. The previous explanation is that the two faculties have dominance over the differences among sentient beings and the differences in discrimination.

It is also said that the life faculty, the five beginning with faith, etc., have a dominant function in the continuance of similar species and in defilement and purification, respectively, and are established as faculties. This is also no different from the previous section, and therefore should not be repeated.
It is also said that the three faculties without outflow are also like this. They have a dominant function in attaining the later paths, nirvÄá¹‡a, etc.

That is, the first faculty has the dominant function with regard to obtaining the second; the second faculty has the dominant function with regard to obtaining the third; and the third faculty has the dominant function with regard to obtaining nirvÄá¹‡a, because one is not able to realize it without this faculty.
It is also not different from the previous, so there is no need to repeat it. It is precisely because it has the dominant function with regard to purity.
Also, the author of the commentary explains that the word â€œalsoâ€ indicates that each one can be a faculty. This is also unreasonable, because there is no need to doubt.

Because the dominant function with regard to obtaining the later paths, nirvÄá¹‡a, etc., is mentioned, the separate meaning has already been established. One should not give rise to doubt again within it.

If it is said that doubt should arise because of the absence of a difference in nature and type, this is also unreasonable. The three stages of seeing, cultivation, and no-more-learning are each different. They do not mutually include each other. One cannot give rise to doubt.
Even if there is the arising of doubt, because the later ones, etc., have already been distinguished, why bother to indicate them by analogy?
Although the natures of the nine faculties are without distinction, there is a distinction in their dominant force. Why would you doubt them?
It should be one faculty, not the female or male faculty, because seeing this gives rise to doubt.

Now we explain that the words of the sutra have another meaning, namely, that apart from the nine there are no separate three faculties. Just as the male and female faculties are established separately from the body faculty, apart from the body faculty there are no separate two faculties.

The three faculties are also like this. Although they are established separately from the nine faculties based on their distinct meanings, they are not separate from the nine and have three faculties. This explanation is reasonable.
The author of the commentary also explains that the word etc. indicates another category.
What is the other category?
Namely, in the cessation of the afflictions that are eliminated by insight and by cultivation, the faculties of one who is to know and one who has known have a dominant force, respectively.

This is also unreasonable. Only the uninterrupted path is called dominant. The path of preparation, the path of liberation, and the path of advancement included in the path of insight and the path of cultivation should not be called faculties.

If it is the case that the four paths are all dominant faculties, then the path of preparation that conforms to penetration, the knowledge of the class of the four truths, etc., have dominance in the cessation of the passions that are to be eliminated by the path of insight, and therefore should be categorized as the first faculty.

The faculty of ultimate knowledge should be categorized as the third faculty, but there are many errors in this interpretation and it is not a good explanation. Now, on the basis of a different interpretation, we explain the term et cetera in the holy teachings. That is, pure understanding has the power of dominance in first attaining realization of the truths that have not been realized, and therefore the first faculty is established.

If pure understanding has already attained realization of the truths, in the gradual elimination of the remaining passions, the power of dominance is established in the hope of the path of added effort, and therefore the second faculty is established.

If pure understanding is already free from the passions, the power of dominance is established in the enjoyment of the present life of all pure dharmas, and therefore the third faculty is established.
Understanding is the leader, and the three kinds of realization are complete, and therefore understanding is mentioned first, and the other eight are established as assisting it.

If it is really the case that the faculties are established on the basis of both, why is it not the case that the faculty of acquiescence in the truths is the first of the faculties, since one has already realized the truths? The seven knowledges are the repeated realization of the truths, and therefore are not included in the first faculty.
Also, because they are separated from acquiescence, they are not included in the second faculty. In that case, the path of liberation should not be called a faculty.

Also, the faculty of perfect knowledge is also the truth, and since one realizes it for the first time, it should be included in the first faculty. In that case, the faculties that are established would be confused.

There is no confusion, because there is a difference between seeing, knowledge, and realization. It is just as in the world, where one who has already realized the truths is said to realize for the first time the pure truths that he had not realized previously.

Also, it is just as suffering and its cause are one thing, but their aspects are different and their realizations are different. If one has not yet ascertained and penetrated the truths, he only realizes the truths by seeing. If one has already ascertained and penetrated them, he is said to realize the truths by knowledge and seeing. Therefore the seven knowledges are said to realize for the first time the truths that were not realized previously.

However, the knowledge of the class of the path does not have the same fault as the knowledge of suffering, etc., because although it is the same as the seven knowledges in one moment, it is different in subsequent continuity, just as the many moments after are called the faculty of having understood. It is not the case in the state of the path of insight.
As for the one moment of the seven knowledges, there is a repeated realization of the truth, and therefore it is not the same as the knowledge of suffering, etc.

However, the knowledge of exhaustion, etc., is like the first moment, and it is also like this in continuity, because it is all able to support the bonds of the passions that are destroyed by the diamond-like samÄdhi, and it causes the acquisition of separation from those bonds to continue.
The author of the commentary should not be the same as this and not have the fault.

Moreover, although the knowledge of the class of the path does not realize the truth in one moment with regard to the object that is observed, it does realize the truth in innumerable moments with regard to the path as object. Therefore, following the majority, it is said that with regard to all objects it is called realization, and it is established as the faculty of having understood.

It is not that one has not yet crossed the great ocean or the wondrous high mountain, because one has not yet crossed the remaining measure of mustard seeds, that one can be called one who has not yet crossed them. This should be the same as that.
Western masters say that the cognition of the class of suffering and the cognition of the class of origination are also included in the faculty of understanding what was not previously understood.
If this is explained in relation to them, this fault is completely absent.
Therefore, what I have said is free from the first two errors.

If something is established as a faculty because it is dominant, then among the afflictions of the class of craving and the class of views, the two dharmas of feeling and conceptualization have a dominant function. Conceptualization should be established as a faculty just as feeling is.
Moreover, among the afflictions, those that have a dominant function in destroying good dharmas, etc., should constitute the substance of a faculty.
Moreover, the faculties are established because they are most excellent. Nirvana is most excellent among all dharmas. Why is it not established as a faculty?
Moreover, KÄpila established speech, hands, feet, and the anus as faculties, because they have a dominant function in speaking, grasping, moving, and expelling.
Such things should not be established as faculties, because the accepted faculties have such characteristics.
Verse:
The mind and its activities depend on this, this abides, and this is defiled,
This is the equipment, this is the purification; by this measure the faculties are established.
The treatise says:
The basis of the mind is the six faculties such as the eye. These six internal bases are the basis of sentient beings.
Their distinctions in characteristics are due to the male and female faculties. Again, due to the life faculty, they abide for a period of time.
Their defilement is due to the five faculties of sensation.
Their equipment for purification is due to the five faculties such as faith.
Their attainment of purification is due to the last three faculties.
By these, the matter of establishing the faculties is all concluded. Thought and the others should not be established as faculties.
Among the afflictions, craving is the most serious fault, therefore only sensation is established as their faculty.
The most serious fault of craving is because a scripture says that craving is the cause for the arising of the six sense bases.
As a scripture says:
Because of craving as a cause, the six sense bases arise.

Also, conceptualization is the cause of the generation of the passions, and the other causes generate the inverted views. Once the inverted views are generated, conceptualization holds them and causes them to continue in a series. Apart from the correct antidote, they cannot be eliminated.
Therefore it is said that conceptualization is the cause of the inverted views.
Feeling is the cause of craving and is of both kinds, because feeling is the most important cause of the passions.
Because it is of both kinds of causes, it is established as a separate faculty.
Other masters say that
conceptualization is not established as a root because it is overwhelmed by other dharmas, that is, good conceptualization is overwhelmed by correct views,
and defiled conceptualization is overwhelmed by inverted views.
Because it is not dominant, it is not established as a root.
Also, the passions are not dominant, because feeling is dominant among them.
Only feeling can be established as a root, because it can destroy good actions and the events that result in happiness.
How can the inferior and contemptible be established as roots?
Because roots are superior dharmas in the world.

Moreover, although nirvÄá¹‡a is superior to all dharmas, it is not established as a root because it destroys the faculties, just as when pots are destroyed, the substance of the pots is not destroyed.
Also, the organs of speech, etc., are not called roots, because they are indefinite and mixed, and because they are subject to great error.
As for the error of indefiniteness, which organ of speech is established as the root of speech?
That which can emit speech is called the organ of speech, and this is precisely the tongue.
If that is so, then such dharmas as applied and sustained thought, and the winds that give rise to the activity of speech, should also be established as roots, because they can emit speech.
This is because the sounds of speech are produced in dependence on the lips, teeth, palate, throat, etc., and are not dependent only on the tongue, because there is no different cause.
Also, because such dharmas as applied and sustained thought are the superior causes for emitting speech.
Also, the hands, armpits, flutes, strings, breath, etc., are all able to be the causes for emitting speech, and therefore the tongue alone should not be established as the organ of speech.
If you say that one understands form because of words, and therefore the eye should not be established as a faculty, this is not reasonable.
Even though blind people hear the word form, they do not understand the characteristics of blue, etc.
The hand should not be called a faculty in grasping, because the mouth, etc., can also grasp things.
The foot should not be called a faculty in locomotion, because snakes, fish, etc., move about without feet.
The anus should not be called a faculty in excretion, because the mouth, etc., can also excrete.

The error of confusion is that the faculties established by them would be confused, because the mouth both grasps and excretes, and the hand and foot both have the function of locomotion. There is this kind of error of confusion.
The error of excess is that the faculties established by them would be unlimited.

If the faculty of the tongue is different from the faculty of speech, then you should admit that the faculty of the nose is different from the faculty of breathing, because the nose, like the tongue, can speak and the nose, like the feet, can breathe.

If something is a faculty because it has some function with regard to something else, then the throat, teeth, lips, stomach, etc., should be considered faculties, because they have predominance with regard to swallowing, chewing, holding, etc.
Or, all causes should be considered faculties, because they all have predominance with regard to the production of their own effects.
Therefore, the theory of KÄpila that the tongue, etc., are faculties is like the play of a child, because it is not established that they are the most predominant, without exception.
There is another master who explains the characteristics of the faculties differently.
A verse says:ğŸ”½Or, the first fourteen are established as the basis of transmigration, birth, abiding, and enjoyment,
And the last three are also so for returning to quiescence.
The treatise says:

The word or indicates that this is the theory of another master. He establishes the faculties based on the most predominant basis of transmigration and returning to quiescence in birth, abiding, and enjoyment.
The meaning of transmigration is the continuity of birth and death. The support of transmigration is the six internal sense bases, because the eye, etc., definitely constitute their intrinsic nature.
Birth is conditioned by the two organs of male and female, because they are the causes of birth.
Abiding is conditioned by the life faculty, because it is the cause of the continuity and non-interruption of that.
Enjoyment is conditioned by feeling, because the five feelings evolve as benefit and harm.

In the state of transmigration, these fourteen faculties are established because of their four superior functions. In the state of cessation and return, the remaining eight faculties are established because of these four superior functions.

The meaning of cessation and return is the cessation of birth and death, which is the final cessation of the six sense bases. The support of this is the five such as faith, because they are the most superior causes for the growth of all wholesome roots.
The first pure faculty is able to produce this attainment, because it is first produced in the stage of correct concentration.
The next pure faculty causes this attainment to abide, because it is produced in a continuous series for a long time.
The last three roots enable one to enjoy the bliss of the present life.
Neither action nor affliction are established as roots, because each individually lacks the power to generate the six sense bases.
If this is so, then the eye, etc., should also not be roots, and the mental faculty, joy, pleasure, and indifference should not be pure, and the five pure roots should not be impure.

This can be said because they are predominant in a certain way, but one should not form a definite concept about them. Action and affliction do not have a definite, unique, predominant function, and therefore they are not established as roots.
We have explained the meaning of the faculties and the reason for their establishment. We must now explain the individual natures of the faculties.
Among them, the eye, etc., up to the male faculty, have already been discussed in this chapter.
That is, the five pure material elements that are the support of the consciousnesses are called the faculties of eye, etc.
The two faculties of female and male are established as distinctions within the body.
The nature of the life faculty is not associated with mind, and it will be extensively distinguished in the section on the dissociated dharmas.
Because faith, etc., are mental activities, they will be extensively distinguished among the mental activities.
The five feelings such as pleasure and the three pure faculties have no other place where they can be discussed, and therefore they must be explained now.
A verse says:
The bodyâ€™s lack of pleasure is called suffering, and this very pleasure is called happiness.
And the mental pleasure of the three trance states is called joy in other places.
Mental lack of pleasure is called sorrow, and there is no distinction between the two middling ones.
The paths of insight, cultivation, and no training are established on the basis of the nine faculties.
The treatise says:
The body refers to bodily feeling, because it arises in dependence on the body. It is the feeling associated with the five consciousnesses.
The term lack of pleasure means injury. That which injures among the feelings of touch associated with the five consciousnesses is called the faculty of suffering.
The term pleasure means benefit. That which benefits among the feelings of touch associated with the five consciousnesses is called the faculty of happiness.
The pleasure associated with the first three consciousnesses in the first trance state is also included in this category, because its kind is the same.
The feeling associated with mental consciousness in the third trance state that benefits is also called the faculty of pleasure.
Because there is no other body of consciousnesses in that stage, that which is associated with mental consciousness and is satisfaction is established as the faculty of pleasure.
There are two kinds of feelings of satisfaction associated with mental consciousness. In the third trance state, it is called pleasure, because in that stage one is free of craving for joy.
In the three stages below the third trance state, it is called the faculty of joy, because there is craving for joy.
These two kinds of mental satisfaction are the same in benefiting, so what is the difference in their modes of activity that they are distinguished as joy and pleasure?
They differ because of the difference in their modes of activity.ğŸ”½If mental satisfaction evolves in a tranquil mode of activity, it is called the faculty of pleasure.
If mental satisfaction evolves in a mode of activity that is gross and agitated, it is called the faculty of joy.
Or, the faculty of pleasure is preeminent in benefiting, while the faculty of joy is not.
Therefore the sages say that the pleasure of the third trance state is a place of indulgence.
The feeling of displeasure associated with mental consciousness is called the faculty of sorrow.
The above four faculties of feeling are established on the basis of the differences in the modes of activity of feelings of pleasure, etc., in relation to body and mind.
The two feelings of indifference are not distinguished, because the meaning of indifference is neither pleasure nor displeasure, and it is called the faculty of indifference.
In what state of consciousness is this feeling of indifference?
It is said that this feeling is found in both mental consciousness and the five consciousnesses.
Why are pleasure and displeasure each divided into two, while neither-pleasure-nor-displeasure is only one?
Because it is not differentiated in body and mind.
Pleasure and displeasure in the mind are mostly agitated, but when pleasure and displeasure are in the body, they are calm and stable.
Neither-pleasure-nor-displeasure in the body and in the mind is the same in mode of activity, only calm and stable.
Also, pleasure and displeasure in the mind are mostly born of discrimination, but this is not so in the body, because they follow the power of the object.

The same is true of the faculties of arhatship, etc. They are born in the same way, and when they are abandoned, they are both in the body and mind, and are not associated with any specific thought. They arise spontaneously in a neutral state.
Also, the feelings of pain and pleasure are in the body and in the mind, and their modes of activity differ in regard to enemies and friends.
The feeling that is neither painful nor pleasant is in the body and in the mind, and its mode of activity is the same in regard to a neutral object.
Therefore, pain and pleasure are each divided into two, and the feeling that is neither painful nor pleasant is established as only one faculty.
The nature of the faculties of pleasure, etc., have been explained. The three pure faculties will now be explained.
It is impossible to explain their natures individually. They should be established in general in the three paths in reliance on the nine faculties.
The mind faculty, the feelings of pleasure, joy, and indifference, and the five faculties such as faith, these nine are the three pure faculties in the three paths.

That is, in the path of insight, the nine dharmas such as the mind faculty are the substance of the faculty of understanding that which has not been understood, because they operate with the mode of activity of understanding that which has not been understood.

If one is in the path of cultivation, the nine dharmas such as intention are the essence of the second faculty of knowing, in order to eliminate the remaining latent tendencies, one repeatedly understands the known objects.

If one is in the path of no-more-learning, the nine dharmas such as intention are the essence of the third faculty of knowing, knowing that one has already known is called knowing, cultivating knowing to form a nature is called knowing, or because one can protect knowing, it is called knowing.
These nine faculties correspond to form this matter, therefore intention and the other eight also obtain this name.
Although the names of these faculties are twenty-two, the actual faculties are only seventeen, because the two faculties of female and male are included in the body faculty;
because the three pure faculties are included in the nine faculties.
Thus the different essences of the faculties have been explained. Next, the distinctions in the meanings of various categories will be discussed.
Among these twenty-two faculties, how many are contaminated and how many are uncontaminated?
Verse:
Only the last three are uncontaminated. The form faculties, life, sorrow, and suffering,
It should be understood that only the last three roots are uncontaminated, while the remaining nine are both contaminated and uncontaminated.
The treatise says:
The last three roots mentioned above are only uncontaminated, which means they are free from defilements.
Defilements and contaminations have different names but the same substance.
The seven material roots, life, and sorrow and suffering are exclusively contaminated.
The seven material ones refer to the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, female, and male roots, because they are included in the form aggregate.

The nine that are both contaminated and uncontaminated are the three uncontaminated roots, which are the mental faculty and so on, called uncontaminated. The remaining mental faculty and so on are called contaminated.
Other masters say:
The five roots such as faith are also exclusively uncontaminated, because the scriptures only say they are possessed by the noble ones.
Moreover, the World-Honored One said:
If one completely lacks these five roots such as faith, I say they abide in the category of ordinary beings outside the path.
This is not a valid proof, because this statement is made based on the uncontaminated roots.
How do we know this?

If you make a different interpretation of these two sÅ«tras that I have cited, I will further refute you with a superior interpretation in accordance with reason. Therefore, the faculties such as faith definitely include both pure and impure dharmas.

The first eight faculties, namely the five sense faculties and the faculties of form, male, and female, and the last three, namely the faculties of suffering, sorrow, and distress, definitely have no retribution, because the first eight are indeterminate and the last three are pure.

Among the twenty-two faculties, how many are bound to the desire realm, how many are bound to the form realm, and how many are bound to the formless realm?

Because this body is ugly.

Because he is powerful in the path of detachment, he is called a man.

Because their bodies are extremely pure and wonderful.

The differences in meanings and categories of the various aspects have already been explained. Next, we will explain the initial attainment of the faculties with retribution. How many faculties with retribution are initially attained in which realm?

Because at the moment of first rebirth, there are no five consciousnesses. The phrase those born from wombs, eggs, or moisture is used to exclude those born supernaturally, because the material faculties of those born supernaturally do not arise gradually.

Those who maintain that past and future do not exist would have no retribution in the three time periods.

Even though they run wild in vain speculation to establish their own doctrines, they must admit that there is a real dharma that is the basis of birth.

How many faculties are eliminated at death in the various realms?

We now discuss the number of faculties that cease at death when the mind is defiled or indeterminate.

Other masters say:
Because they have form. If you do not admit that there is a real entity called life faculty, what is it that is destroyed to cause the death of beings in the formless realms?
